Derwent win in final game on the JLD

23/05/2014

Derwent firsts played some excellent football to beat Alcuin firsts in the final College Cup game on the JLD, bringing the era of Cup matches on the surface to an end

Image by

By undefined undefined

DERWENT FIRSTS 4-1 ALCUIN FIRSTS Group A Derwent firsts put on a show on Friday, as they beat Alcuin firsts 4-1 in the final College Cup game on the JLD before it is demolished in the coming weeks. Last year's losing Cup finalists named a strong side against the other firsts team in Group A, and could have been ahead with less than 30 seconds on the clock when Eddie Fotheringham sent a shot crashing against the bar when it seemed easier to score. It was a bright start from Derwent though, with Fotheringham, Josh Bew and Jamie Trant all looking dangerous in the opening minutes. There was then a moment of humour on five minutes as the ball was headed out of play; Halifax player Guy Bowden tried to control the ball whilst stood on a bench, but tipped it up and collapsed into the fencing to the amusement of the gathered support. Derwent in particular were playing nice, attacking football on the floor, but Alcuin were by no means absent early on and looked threatening when Andy Fernando, Jeremy Nestor and Sam Hinchcliffe put a nice move together which resulted in the latter getting a shot away. However, Felix Aylett between the Derwent sticks had it covered. Ben Carver then skewed a potshot from 15 yards wide of Aylett's post, and despite some relatively good build-up play, Alcuin could not make their way into the box, being restricted to long-range efforts. Derwent, however, were pressing high with an attacking 4-2-3-1 formation, and recycling the ball with ease in the middle of the park through Mirhire Overo-Tarimo and Joe Easter. On ten minutes, Derwent attacked with intent and Easter left a nice ball in the area for front-man Fotheringham to latch onto, but he couldn't beat Neil Lawrence in the Owls' goal. Ryan Gwinnett then delivered a well-struck free kick which found the head of Bew, and it looked as though Derwent's first goal was inevitable. However, Alcuin then took the lead against the run of play; after some incisive attacking play, Carver thumped a powerful shot against the crossbar, and after a scramble, Luca Nazzicone found the back of the net to put the men in red and black into the lead. This saw the start of a good spell in the game in which both sides were working tirelessly to win and keep possession. Both were pressing high, allowing their opponents little time on the ball and playing at a high tempo. Nevertheless, as torrential rain began to bounce down onto the JLD surface, Derwent grabbed their equaliser, from which they never looked back. Mark Askham pumped in a cross into the area, which Bew sent into the back of the net with a brilliant looping header past Lawrence. The sides then went in level at the break. The game was affected by the rain in the second half, but Derwent stepped up another gear to rack up another three goals. Early in the second period, Easter went close on two occasions to grab a goal, while Bew was continually causing problems for Christos Tuton and Sean Perera. Fotheringham then thought he'd put Derwent ahead, but the ball was hacked off the line by Nazzicone. The men in black and blue were keeping the ball well and dominating the possession stats, and as Alex d'Albertanson and Mike Whittall replaced Gwinnett and Askham respectively, they looked comfortable. Alcuin were continually pushing themselves though, and Leonidas Kanonis and Jeremy Nestor in the middle were working hard to create openings. This was undone with twenty minutes remaining, when Jamie Trant found the net to put Derwent 2-1 ahead, although the Alcuin players seemed certain that he was offside. Nevertheless, the goal stood and knocked the wind out of Alcuin's sails. Chasing the game, they had to leave themselves open at the back and Derwent took full advantage, as Fotheringham slotted Trant's cross increase their winning margin to two goals. And despite Alcuin's constant efforts to find another goal, it became four with just a couple of minutes left as Overo-Tarimo scored one of the goals of the tournament so far, with a great shot from 20 yards out. Derwent saw the game out with ease in the last couple of minutes to take a 4-1 victory, and the game brought the College Cup era on the JLD to a close, as the pitch closed for the final time on Friday. After the match, Derwent captain Dave Belshaw told Nouse, "It's nice to close the JLD with a win. I'm not sure I'm going to miss it though, the surface isn't great for playing football on! I was really pleased with our game today, we went down early but we didn't panic, kept playing our football and kept getting better and better. Maybe Jamie Trant's goal was a touch offside, but we won 4-1 at the end of the day so I think we'd have gone on to win the game anyway." By contrast, disappointed Alcuin skipper Greg Fearn said, "It's three weeks in a row now that a refereeing decision has cost us. It's starting to get on my nerves. But when you come up against teams like that, we know we've not necessarily got the same quality, so we need an extra bit of effort and I can't fault our lads at all. We had to try and get the second goal, but I think 4-1 flatters them." Derwent: Aylett, Askham (Whittall), Shelbourn, Brandreth, Harrison, Overo-Tarimo, Easter, Gwinnett (d'Albertanson), Trant, Bew, Fotheringham. Man of the Match: Josh Bew Alcuin: Lawrence, Nazzicone, Tuton, Perera, McConnell, Fearn, Kanonis, Nestor, Fernando, Hinchcliffe, Carver. Used subs: Kc, Bugeja. Man of the Match: Leonidas Kanonis
